document.title: Physical Education Content Standards and Benchmarks

2C1AE0A0DFE601317E8B68A86D17958E.description: Identifies the differences between idealized body images and elite performance levels portrayed by the media and their own personal characteristics and skills.

2C1A9F70DFE601317E8A68A86D17958E.description: Identifies the emotions they are feeling while participating in a variety of physical activities.

2C1A4AC0DFE601317E8968A86D17958E.description: Demonstrates Level 1 performance in the following:

2C1A0430DFE601317E8868A86D17958E.description: Chooses to participate in a physical activity for novelty and challenge.

2C19C050DFE601317E8768A86D17958E.description: Chooses to participate in a physical activity for enjoyment.

2C197D00DFE601317E8668A86D17958E.description: Chooses to participate in physical activities alone and with others.

2C193AD0DFE601317E8568A86D17958E.description: Expresses verbal and nonverbal indicators of enjoyment while participating in physical activities.

2C18F9E0DFE601317E8468A86D17958E.description: Demonstrates Level 2 performance in the following:

2C18B5E0DFE601317E8368A86D17958E.description: K-2 Student expectations (by the end of grade 2)
comments: Young children are the most active segment of our population. They are physically active because they enjoy merely participating. Students like the challenge of experiencing new movements and learning new skills. They feel joy as they gain competence in them. They begin to function as members of a group and to work cooperatively for brief periods of time.

2C186700DFE601317E8268A86D17958E.description: A physically educated person values physical activity for health, enjoyment, challenge, self-expression, and/or social interaction.

2C1821F0DFE601317E8168A86D17958E.description: Exhibits behaviors which exemplify each of the following personal/social character traits: constructive competition and initiative.

2C17DB10DFE601317E8068A86D17958E.description: Recognizes the benefits of possessing each of the following personal/social character traits: responsibility, best effort, cooperation, and compassion.

2C178AE0DFE601317E7F68A86D17958E.description: Demonstrates Level 1 performance in the following:

2C173100DFE601317E7E68A86D17958E.description: Exhibits behaviors which exemplify each of the following personal/social character traits: responsibility, best effort, cooperation, and compassion.

2C16CDC0DFE601317E7D68A86D17958E.description: Identifies key behaviors which exemplify each of the following personal/social character traits: responsibility, best effort, cooperation, and compassion.

2C166A20DFE601317E7C68A86D17958E.description: Demonstrates Level 2 performance in the following:

2C162830DFE601317E7B68A86D17958E.description: K-2 Student expectations (by the end of grade 2)
comments: Young children discover the joy of playing with friends and experience how social interaction can make activities more fun. They know safe practices and physical education class rules and procedures, and they are able to apply them with little or no reinforcement. Children know how to utilize acceptable behaviors for physical activity settings and are building a foundation for successful interpersonal communication during group activity. By improving motor skills, children have gained a basis and appreciation for working with others in cooperative movement, sharing, working together to solve a problem, and/or tackling a challenge.

2C15EAA0DFE601317E7A68A86D17958E.description: A physically educated person exhibits responsible personal and social behavior that respects self and others in physical activity settings.

2C15AC80DFE601317E7968A86D17958E.description: Meets criterion-referenced age- and gender-specific, health-related fitness standards (e.g., Fitnessgram, President's Challenge, and Brockport Physical Fitness Test).

2C156B90DFE601317E7868A86D17958E.description: Identifies that the body is made up of lean body mass and body fat.

2C152C50DFE601317E7768A86D17958E.description: Demonstrates flexibility through a full range of motion of the major joints.

2C14EA80DFE601317E7668A86D17958E.description: Supports own body weight in selected activities to develop muscular strength and endurance (e.g., climbing, hanging, hopping, jumping, animal walks, and stunts).

2C149DE0DFE601317E7568A86D17958E.description: Sustains moderate to vigorous levels of physical activity that cause increased heart rate, breathing rate, perspiration, etc., (e.g., running, galloping, skipping, and hopping).

2C145DC0DFE601317E7468A86D17958E.description: Recognizes that there are five components of health-related fitness.

2C1416A0DFE601317E7368A86D17958E.description: K-2 Student expectations (by the end of grade 2)
comments: Young children engage in a variety of activities that serve to promote health-related physical fitness. They enjoy physical activities for the pleasure experienced from simply moving and may not associate the activity with the development of physical fitness. They participate in physical activity intermittently for short periods of time, will accumulate a relatively high volume of total activity, and have fun while doing so. They recognize physiological signs associated with participation in moderate to vigorous physical activity (e.g., sweating, fast heart rate, and heavy breathing). Students at this level possess basic knowledge of the components of health-related fitness (e.g., cardiorespiratory endurance, muscular strength and endurance, flexibility, and body composition).

2C13D800DFE601317E7268A86D17958E.description: A physically educated person achieves and maintains a health-enhancing level of physical fitness.

2C139840DFE601317E7168A86D17958E.description: Participating daily in a variety of non-structured and minimally-organized physical activities outside of physical education.

2C1357C0DFE601317E7068A86D17958E.description: Participating in chasing and fleeing activities in and outside of physical education.

2C1313E0DFE601317E6F68A86D17958E.description: Participating in a variety of developmentally-appropriate physical activities that incorporate manipulative skills in and outside of physical education.

2C12C0C0DFE601317E6E68A86D17958E.description: Participating in a variety of locomotor activities in and outside of physical education.

2C126C90DFE601317E6D68A86D17958E.description: Participating primarily in physical activities that focus on skill building rather than on formal game structure.

2C121D30DFE601317E6C68A86D17958E.description: Intermittently engages in physical activities that are moderate to vigorous in intensity while:

2C11BB50DFE601317E6B68A86D17958E.description: K-2 Student expectations (by the end of grade 2)
comments: Young children participate in physical activities largely because of the pleasure they experience. They engage primarily in non-structured physical activities, on an intermittent basis, outside of physical education class and have fun while doing so. They participate in a wide variety of gross motor activities that involve locomotion, non-locomotion, and manipulation of objects. Students knowingly select and participate in activities during their leisure time that are moderate to vigorous in nature and that they find enjoyable. They recognize that participation in moderate to vigorous physical activity has both temporary and lasting effects on the body and voluntarily chose to engage in activities that contribute to improved health. Students begin to utilize the skills and knowledge acquired in physical education class during their leisure-time physical activity.

2C1178B0DFE601317E6A68A86D17958E.description: A physically educated person participates regularly in lifelong physical activity.

2C112900DFE601317E6968A86D17958E.description: Distinguishes among the critical elements of the following non-manipulative skills: balance, bending, stretching, rocking, rolling, curling, twisting, turning, pushing, pulling, swinging, swaying, and landing.

2C10CF10DFE601317E6868A86D17958E.description: Distinguishes among the critical elements of the following locomotor skills: walk, run, leap, jump, skip, hop, gallop, slide, chase, flee, and dodge.

2C1083C0DFE601317E6768A86D17958E.description: Distinguishes among the critical elements of the following manipulative skills: roll, under hand throw, and overhand throw.

2C0FFFF0DFE601317E6568A86D17958E.description: Demonstrates Level 2 performance in the following:

2C0FB150DFE601317E6468A86D17958E.description: Limited identification of front float, back float, and recovery. Identifies how to enter and exit the pool safely, water safety rules, use of a life jacket, and how to get help (American Red Cross/Whales Tales).

2C0F7060DFE601317E6368A86D17958E.description: Limited identification of the critical elements of manipulative skills: catch, kick, hand and foot dribble, and strike.

2C0F28B0DFE601317E6268A86D17958E.description: Demonstrates Level 1 performance in the following:

2C0EE870DFE601317E6168A86D17958E.description: K-2 Student expectations (by the end of grade 2)
comments: Young children are rapidly maturing in their basic cognitive abilities. They learn and apply concepts such as actions, planes, and personal/general space. They identify and perform concepts of effort and relationships that vary the quality of movement. Students identify elements of correct form for fundamental skills and use them in performance. They use feedback to improve motor performance.

2C0EA4D0DFE601317E6068A86D17958E.description: A physically educated person demonstrates understanding of movement concepts, principles, strategies, and tactics as they apply to the learning and performance of physical activities.

2C0E6360DFE601317E5F68A86D17958E.description: Basic front float, back float, and recovery. Uses a combination of arms and legs to swim. Demonstrates ability to enter and exit pool safely and use a life jacket (American Red Cross/Whales Tales).

2C0E2150DFE601317E5E68A86D17958E.description: Demonstrates Level 1 performance in the following:

2C0DDD90DFE601317E5D68A86D17958E.description: Movement concepts in the following manipulative skills: catch, kick, hand and foot dribble, and strike.

2C0D9570DFE601317E5C68A86D17958E.description: Movement concepts in the following manipulative skills: overhand throw, underhand throw, and roll.

2C0D4A90DFE601317E5B68A86D17958E.description: Movement concepts including the following locomotor skills: walk, run, leap, jump, skip, hop, gallop, slide, chase, flee, and dodge.

2C0CFDC0DFE601317E5A68A86D17958E.description: Using selected movement concepts with non-manipulative skills including the following: balance, bending, stretching, rocking, rolling, curling, twisting, turning, pushing, pulling, swinging, swaying, and landing.

2C0CAE30DFE601317E5968A86D17958E.description: Selected movement concepts in the following: spatial awareness, effort, and relationships.

2C0C6000DFE601317E5868A86D17958E.description: Demonstrates Level 2 performance in the following:

2C0C14D0DFE601317E5768A86D17958E.description: K-2 Student expectations (by the end of grade 2)
comments: Young children are very active and enjoy learning and mastering new ways to move and be active. Students achieve mature forms in the basic locomotor skills and vary the manner in which these skills are performed in relationship to changing conditions and expectations. They demonstrate smooth transitions between sequential locomotor skills. Students show progress toward achieving mature form in the more complex manipulative skills (e.g., foot dribble) and achieve mature form in the less complex manipulative skills (e.g., underhand throw). They demonstrate control in traveling, weight-bearing, and balance activities on a variety of body parts.

2C0BC620DFE601317E5668A86D17958E.description: A physically educated person demonstrates competency in motor skills and movement patterns needed to perform a variety of physical activities.
